huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
This unit has spectacular scenery with many tourists, fishermen, and campers utilizing the area during the summer months. Many visitors to this area travel here specifically to view bighorn sheep.

This hunt allows hunters to scout and hunt from land or from a boat. This unit is small with a low sheep population. Many of the mature rams congregate in 1 to 2 groups most of the year.

Herd numbers have been declining and older rams have been dying before being harvested. Hunters should expect a class III or 3/4 curl (score 140-150) type ram.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to travel to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two until through the first week of October.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~450 (entire High Uintas area)~145 (entire High Uintas area)~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:
Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep are found in steep rocky terrain. Choose your shot wisely. Make sure it is in a safe place to harvest your bighorn sheep. If you cannot safely retrieve the bighorn sheep, do not shoot.

Scouting Tips:
The bighorn sheep stay fairly consistently in the same general areas throughout much of the year. Once the rut starts, the rams will be begin to move to where the ewes are. Scouting is a good way to see what size of ram you can expect to harvest. Scores for sheep on Bare Top are usually in the 140s-150s and are 5.5-6.5 years old.

Behavior:
Like other wildlife, they are most active in the early mornings and evenings, but they can be up and moving any time of day. Most of the time they are in steep terrain, but they occasionally move down to the shoreline or up on top of Bare Top where itâ€™s flat. Mature rams seem to hang out more in steeper cliffs than ewes. Ewes with lambs prefer areas that are a little less steep and where they can find better feed. Bighorn sheep will usually go to water at least once a day.

Ram vs Ewe:
Both rams and ewes have horns. Ram horns are much larger than ewe horns and will form a curl.

Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep rut:
The bighorn rut runs during November.

Where to find Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep:
Bighorn sheep like steep cliffy areas because it provides an escape from predators. You can find them on grassy flats or near the shoreline when they are eating or come down to drink.

Recommended areas:
There are a couple of areas that the sheep use regularly. These areas include Hideout, Boars Tusk, along the Flaming Gorge Reservoir shoreline and along the Green River below the dam to Little Hole. Hunters that access the area by boat tend to have better success and satisfaction.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: After harvesting a bighorn sheep, you must bring the horns to a DWR office within 72 hours of leaving your hunting area. Checking in a bighorn sheep will fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement. If you received a bighorn sheep permit and did not hunt or did not harvest, you must complete your harvest survey online or by calling toll-free 1-800-221-0659 within 30 days of the season end date printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you being unable to apply for big game permits in subsequent years.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: 90% Public Land - US Forest Service lands, BLM, and State
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and BLM. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: County Road Access information: http://www.daggettcounty.org/index.aspx?nid=17 and http://www.utahcommuterlink.com/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service or BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. There is no vehicle access allowed on Baretop.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/ashley/home/?cid=STELPRDB5432815
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit does not include Tribal Trust Lands and does not have much private land included.  Hunters should receive written permission from private landowners prior to the start of the hunts if they wish to hunt private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett County--Boundary begins at the Flaming Gorge Reservoir main channel western shoreline on the east side of Lucerne Point at the Utah-Wyoming state line; east on this state line to the Utah-Colorado state line; south on this state line to the Green River; west along this river to the Flaming Gorge Reservoir west shoreline; west along this shoreline to the Utah-Wyoming state line; east along the state line to Lucerne Point; east around Lucerne Point to the Utah-Wyoming State line. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
